html:
Gripped by Crazy Love, a true story

If you and I met at one of our children's birthday parties, in the hallway at work, or at a neighbor's barbecue, you'd never guess my secret: that as a young woman I fell in love with and married a man who beat me regularly and nearly killed me.

We need more bikeshare stations, but where?

Capital Bikeshare has been a hit since it started September 20th. There are 4,480 members and a total of 52,000 trips have been taken.

Swinging for a Moment

My daughter Katherine and I arrive about 15 minutes early to pick up Peyton, her older sister, from soccer practice. Being perpetually late, these extra minutes are a gift of sorts--think of all the phone calls I can return?

The coming zoning fight

Next Monday, CAG will hold its November meeting and the topic of the night will be zoning. While this topic sounds a bit dry at first, it is an incredibly important topic for the future of Georgetown and the city at large.

"It's Perfectly Normal" Took Unusual Perseverance

Monday night I attended a reception for the children's author Robie Harris, held at the home of friends in Georgetown.

Roof Terrace Restaurant at The Kennedy Center Toasts Old Dominion

You had me at Thibaut-Janisson. Master vintner Claude Thibaut’s Reim roots have been firmly planted in Monticello soil.

CSAAC High Rollers Night

DJ Kirk McEwen of Classic Rock Radio 105.9 The Edge and special guests including Miss DC 2010, Stephanie Williams and H.E.
Petco Repeating CVS’s Old Mistakes

Dr. T: Battle Against Winter Dry Skin Begins Now

With the onset of winter weather, dry skin becomes a bigger problem due to cold windy weather conditions and hot forced air from heating systems. As such, it’s that much more important in winter to moisturize dry, damaged skin.

Where crime happens in Georgetown

The District of Columbia Crime Policy Institute released a fascinating map yesterday that details crime levels for each census block in the city. Above is a detail of the map showing Georgetown.
Dangerous Beauty

What the Georgetown Metropolitan likes for breakfast

Yesterday Georgetowner Carol Joynt profiled a few of her favorite breakfast spots in Georgetown for the New York Social Diary. They included Four Seasons, Furins, and Baked and Wired.

From GGW and DCist, GM learned yesterday that DDOT is considering adding several new Circulat

As fresh as it gets: fall renewal at Adolfo Dominguez

"I'm not a shopper, I'm a buyer," said superlobbyist Mike Berman of The Duberstein Group the other night at Keith Lipert Gal

Tudor Place sent back to the drawing board

Last Thursday, Tudor Place came before the Old Georgetown Board to seek approval for the concept of its proposed master construction plan.

Hyde-Addison Step Up + Get Down fundraiser nets $70,000

Parents, faculty and supporters of Hyde-Addison Elementary School in Georgetown held their annual auction and dance party amidst a dazzling array of donated items and class projects created by the students decorating the room, raising over $70,000 to expand the school's edible ga

Saving Afghanistan one Silk Scarf at a Time

East met West on M Street recently for "An Evening in the Gardens of Kabul," celebrating the talents of Afghan women at Keith Lipert Gallery.

Q St. Construction to Last Until March

WASA–now branded “DC Water”–has been conducting major construction on Q St. for about a year. The construction entails separating the sewer systems into two systems: sanitary and storm. As it is now, all sewage, whether from a toilet or a storm grate, goes into the same pipe.

Fashion for Paws Featured in photo show

On Thursday evening event ‘models,’ some four-legged friends and a bevy of guests joined host Dan Swartz of Revamp.com at L2 for a reception featuring some of the best photos from Fashion for Paws 2010.

Cap-and-trade expert leaves Obama, returns to GU

Lisa Heinzerling, the Environmental Protection Agency’s associate policy administrator, will step down at the end of the year and return her teaching position at Georgetown Law, reports

Hyde-Addison: a school to be proud of

During the time that I have been raising my now school-age boys in Georgetown, I have had many conversations with my friends and neighbors about schools and education.

Home Sweet Home

It’s been a big week for me. I moved into my own home. As an interior designer and first-time home buyer, this is one of the most thrilling endeavors of my adult life. I’ve had apartments and condos and shared houses, but this is a real “grown up” house and a place of my own.

Halloween, crime, and Georgetown

At the ANC meeting Monday night, Ed Solomon reported that Georgetown is experiencing a crime spike.

ANC Round Up: Traffic Alert Edition

Monday night the ANC met for its November session. Thankfully it was a short agenda, but really all that means is that they’ll find a way to stretch out the proceedings (actually in all fairness they finished up relatively early).

From the soul of a magician: Michel Richard’s Sweet Magic dessert cookbook

As of today you can add dessert cookbook author and illustrator to his resume. You know him best as Citronelle and Central’s master chef/restaurateur but first he was Michel Richard, teenage master pastry chef from Brittany.

Balance. Found in Georgetown?

Balance. Finding it is helpful in motherhood--or anything, for that matter. Einstein said, “Life is like riding a bicycle. To keep your balance, you must keep moving.” As Moms, we move forward with our strollers, in the carpool line, on the soccer field.

Sanity prevails...for at least a few hours

On Saturday, October 30th, a sea of humanity gathered in the shadow of the Capitol and the monuments.

Putting on the Dog

It was a howling good time on the patio of J & G Steakhouse at the W Hotel on Thursday evening as guests and their pets gathered for a Fashion for Paws Halloween Pawtini Happy Hour to benefit The Washington Humane Society.

Diabolique

Day's end greets you with a chill in the air.Skin is paler. Moods are darker.The blanket of night feels sinister and foreboding.... Autumn is the perfect foil for Halloween.As much as I love sunshine and the inherent joys of summer, come October I’m ready for a little kill and thrill.

Panamanian Musical Interludes

Guests gathered at the residence of the Ambassador of Panama via invitation from Fundacion Panama on Monday evening to enjoy an evening of fashion and music to benefit Fundación Sinfonía Concertante de Panamá, an organization that promotes the e

ANC Meeting Monday: GM's Judge For Yourself Edition

After GM had his say yesterday on the ANC, you can come to the ANC meeting Monday, November 1, and see the ANC in action for yourself.

Halloween Tricks and Treats in Georgetown

Halloween started early in Georgetown, with sold out performances of The Picnic Theatre Co.'s production of "An Evening with Edgar Allan Poe" at Dumbarton House Thursday and Friday.

Couple boats and bikes via Georgetown

Eileen Smith nudged a sparkling new silver bicycle into the rack outside Trader Joe's recently to pick up a few supplies before dinner. But she and her husband E. Don -- who frequent the store -- weren't headed back to their house.

Shhh! Rendez-vous at the Ritz is Still a Secret

It's threatening rain, but you're in front of a fireplace surrounded by brick walls in a beautiful Great Room with a piano. You've come for half-price wine and to see friends. But wait. Sitting a few yards away are familiar faces. They're neighbors. You haven't seen them in a year.

Thirty Years Ago GU Students Were Just As Good At Ruining Their Lives

The police arrived before the sun was fully up. They took several Georgetown University students under custody on drug related charges. The campus was shocked to hear the news. By noon it was clear the arrested students’ lives were changed forever.

Alessi is more

Granted, the copper gets polished once in a blue moon, but the only cookware I’ve used for 20 years is Alessi’s La Cintura di Orione. Although I may have been tempted, no new saucepan -- nary a pot -- has taken a place in my kitchen since the Alessi set entered.

Danny DeVito Hasn't Seen "One Sane Person" Since Arriving in D.C.

In a candid chat, Danny DeVito talked about the film business, foster care, legalizing marijuana and much more at a private dinner at Cafe Milano prior to the National Italian American Foundation gala.

Two more Capital Bikeshare stations open in Georgetown

Georgetown’s next two Capital Bikeshare have opened. The first one is located on the east sidewalk of Wisconsin just south of the canal. the second is in front of the British School on Wisconsin Avenue.

Tommy Hilfiger, Michaele Salahi and Fashion Fight MS

The glitterati and paparazzi were out in force at The Washington Club Tuesday evening for Fashion Fight MS—raising funds for the National MS Society.

Hollywood on the Potomac: McAuliffe and Masri at Milano

Before speaking with "A Night for Tomorrow's Youth" benefit organizer Hani Masri at Cafe Milano, Niteside caught up with co-host and former DNC Chair Terry McAuliffe about the mid-term elections and the Clinton magic. Rep.

Think Pink

In honor of Breast Cancer Awareness Month, I am saluting one of my favorite colors - pink. This lovely hue often gets a bad rap. People think it’s a saccharine shade that should be reserved for little girls’ bedrooms and bubble gum.

Susan G. Komen Gala at The Kennedy Center

"Honoring the Promise" Gala at The Kennedy Center on Sunday night celebrated the 30th Anniversary of Nancy G. Brinker's promise to her sister that she help rid the world of breast cancer.

A Mad Men for all Four Seasons

With the soundtracks of Seasons 1 and 2 piped into the lobby of the Four Seasons Hotel, all you needed was to follow the whiff of Beef Stroganoff to find the celebration of Mad Men’s 4th Season Finale taking place in the private dining room of Michael

The Spirit of Georgetown

Guests gathered at the historic home of Niloo and David Howe as the Georgetown Ministry Center presented the 2010 Spirit of Georgetown Benefit. This year’s event honored Rev.

Contemporaria founder extends artful offerings with Alessi

Peruvian Mario Vargas Llosa just won the Nobel Prize for Literature.

Hardy "sex test" program on-hold as Gray weighs in

Hardy Middle School Principal Dana Nerenberg put a controversial HIV/AIDS education program "on hold" as parents and education experts raised new concerns about apparent violations of standards associated with a controversial "sex test" administered at the school without parental

Rhee rheesigns, Henderson named interim schools chief

Kaya Henderson, a deputy of schools chancellor Michelle Rhee, was named interim schools chancellor as Rhee ended a controversial era by announcing her resignation at a press conference joined by Mayor Adrian Fenty and presumptive mayor-elect

Uncle Junior lunches, where else but Georgetown's Il Canale

The only actor to have appeared in the greatest mobster movie series (as Johnny Ola in The Godfather II) and as a regular in the greatest mobster TV series (as Uncle Junior on The Sopranos), Dominic Chianese was spotted Tuesday afternoon at Il Canale

Parents upset by "sex test" at Hardy Middle School

When she picked up her 12-year-old son at Hardy Middle School last Tuesday afternoon, "Susan" knew something was wrong. Her son looked "disturbed," his father said later. Susan asked her son what had happened at school.

Eating for a good cause at the 17th Annual Taste of Georgetown

If you were anywhere within a 10 block radius of Georgetown Saturday, the wafting aromas and grilling smoke signals would have drawn you to Wisconsin and M Streets for the 17th Annual Taste of Georgetown.
